At that time, the bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha, BhagavÄn! BhagavÄn! Are the lifespans of these buddhas
and tathÄgatas equal in length?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us,
Listen attentively, I will explain for you.

Bhiká¹£us!ğŸ”½One kalpa in my SahÄ world, ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha's country, is one day and night in the Land of Bliss.ğŸ”½One kalpa in the Land of Bliss, AmitÄbha Buddha's country, is one day and night in the KÄá¹£Äyadhvaja world.
One kalpa in the KÄá¹£Äyadhvaja world, Buddha of Crushed Vajra's country, is one day and night in the world of Non-Retrogression Wheel Roar, Buddha of Good and Bright PadmÄá¹…kuÅ›a's country.
One eon in the world of the non-retreating wheel is one day and night in the world of no defilements, the realm of the TathÄgata Dharma Banner.

One eon in the world of no defilements is one day and night in the world of good lamps, the realm of the TathÄgata Lion.ğŸ”½One eon in the world of good lamps is one day and night in the world of good light, the realm of the TathÄgata Vairocana Treasury.
One eon in the world of good light is one day and night in the world of difficulty overcoming, the realm of the TathÄgata Dharma Light Lotus Adorned Body.
One eon in the world of difficulty overcoming is one day and night in the world of adorned wisdom, the realm of the TathÄgata Universal Light.
One eon in the world of adorned wisdom is one day and night in the world of mirror wheel light, the realm of the TathÄgata Moon Wisdom.
Bhiká¹£us!

Entering such numbers, it is fulfilled and exceeds ten asaá¹ƒkhyeya hundreds of thousands of myriads of worlds. In the last world, called Padma-viÅ›iá¹£á¹­ha, in the Buddha land of the TathÄgata Buddha Bhadra-viÅ›iá¹£á¹­ha, it is one day and one night.
Bhiká¹£us!
Such worlds are immeasurable and boundless, with different lengths and shorts. The lifespans and abodes of the Buddhas and TathÄgatas are also like this.
Bhiká¹£us!
You should all chant the names of these Buddhas, saying like this:

Homage to the Buddha Sarva-vibhÅ«. At that time, the bhiká¹£u Upagupta rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, and said to the Buddha:ğŸ”½World-Honored One!
World-Honored One!
How many Buddhas have passed away?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£u Upagupta:
Bhiká¹£u!
It is like the world systems as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, from the water level below to the peak of existence above, filled with fine dust.
Bhiká¹£u!

If someone takes that much fine dust, passes through world systems as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and drops one particle, and continues like this, passing through world systems as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, dropping a particle each time, until all that fine dust is used up,
bhiká¹£u!
What do you think?
Can the number of particles that are dropped and the number of particles that are not dropped be known?
The bhiká¹£u said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£u:
Bhiká¹£u!
The number of those dust motes can be known, but the number of those past Buddhas of the same name ÅšÄkyamuni who have already entered parinirvÄá¹‡a cannot be known.
Bhiká¹£us!
I know those past Buddhas as if seeing them right before my eyes.

The mothers of those Buddhas were all named MahÄmÄyÄ, their fathers were all named Åšuddhodana, their cities were all named Kapilavastu, their foremost Å›rÄvaka disciples were all named ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana, and their attendant disciples were all named Ä€nanda. How much more so for the various mothers with different names, fathers with different names, cities with different names, disciples with different names, and attendants with different names.
Bhiká¹£us!

In those many worlds, in which worlds did that person place dust motes, and in which worlds did he not place dust motes? Those worlds, whether dust motes were placed in them or not, extend from the water's edge below to the peak of existence above.
Bhiká¹£us!ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

There is a second person who takes one dust mote and passes through worlds equal in number to those dust motes, and through buddha lands equal in number to the asaá¹ƒkhyeya, koá¹­i, nayuta, one hundred thousand worlds, as one step.
Bhiká¹£us!

That person again passes through worlds equal in number to those dust motes as one step, and that person thus walks for asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas equal in number to koá¹­is of nayutas of one hundred thousand worlds, placing down one dust mote each time, in this way exhausting all the dust motes.
Bhiká¹£us!
In this way, worlds equal in number to those dust motes are filled with dust motes, and more are placed in the worlds of the ten directions.
Bhiká¹£us!
Again, worlds beyond those worlds are filled with dust motes, and those worlds, from the water level below to the peak of existence above, are filled with dust motes.
Bhiká¹£us!
What do you think? Can the number of those dust motes be known?
The bhiká¹£us said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

The number of those dust motes can be known, but the number of those with the same name as mother, the same name as father, the same name as city, the same name as disciple, the same name as attendant, and the same name as ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha cannot be known.
Just as with ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha, it is the same with Abhibhu Banner Buddha, it is the same with Vairocana Buddha, and it is the same with VimalaprabhÄsa Buddha.
It is the same with PrabhÄsa-viÅ›uddha-rÄja Buddha.
It is the same with VimalaprabhÄsa-netra Buddha.
It is the same with Subha-vimalaviÅ›uddha Buddha.
It is the same with AcintyÄprameya-guá¹‡a-sÄgara-siddha-rÄja Buddha.

It is the same with RatnaprabhÄsa Buddha, it is the same with ÅšÄnta-bhÅ«mi Buddha, it is the same with Åšabda-Å›rÄ« Buddha, it is the same with PÄrijÄta Buddha, it is the same with SÅ«rya-candra Buddha, and it is the same with Samanta-ratna-chattra Buddha.
Bhiká¹£us!
You should take refuge in these asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of buddhas with the same name.ğŸ”½Bhiká¹£us!

If good men and good women uphold the names of these Buddhas, they will certainly attain nonretrogression from Bodhi.
Namo to the Buddha Supreme Sandalwood in the world of Nanda. If good men and good women uphold the name of this Buddha, they will ultimately attain a pure mind.

Namo to the Buddha Pacifying Defilements in the world of Bhadra. Namo to the Buddha Overcoming Mara's Power in the world of intention, wisdom, and Kaituo. Namo to the Buddha Without Sorrow in the world of full moon. Namo to the Buddha Jewel Staff in the world of Kaituo's superior intention. Namo to the Buddha Flower Superior in the world of superior voice of speech. Namo to the Buddha Three Conquering in the world of Chamara. Namo to the Buddha Tree Superior in the world of vastness. Namo to the Buddha Vajra Meritorious Body in the world of moon superior. Namo to the Buddha Supreme in the ocean of immeasurable and boundless past. If good men chant the name of that Buddha, they will attain the ultimately irreversible bodhi mind.

Furthermore, the bhiká¹£u MahÄnÄman asked the TathÄgata again:
World-Honored One!
How many Buddhas have entered nirvana in the past?
The Buddha told MahÄnÄman:
Listen carefully now, I will explain it to you.
Bhiká¹£us!
In the worlds to the east, south, west, north, above and below, as many worlds as there are sands in the Ganges River, from the bottom of the water to the peak of existence, filled with fine dust.
Bhiká¹£us!
What do you think, can the number of those fine dust motes be known?
The bhiká¹£us said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The number of ÅšÄkyamuni Buddhas who have entered nirvana in the past cannot be known.
Bhiká¹£us!
I know those past Buddhas as if they were right before my eyes.

The mothers of those buddhas all had the same name, MahÄmÄyÄ, the fathers all had the same name, Åšuddhodana, the cities all had the same name, Kapilavastu, the foremost disciples of those buddhas all had the same names, ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana, the attendants of those buddhas all had the same name, Ä€nanda. How much less could there be various different names for mothers, fathers, cities, disciples, and attendants?
Bhiká¹£us!

In those worlds, in which worlds did that person place a particle, and in which worlds did he not place a particle? Those worlds, whether particles were placed in them or not, from the bottom of the water to the peak of existence.
Bhiká¹£us!

There was a second person who took those particles, and in as many worlds as there are particles, in as many buddha lands as there are asaá¹ƒkhyeya, koá¹­i, nayuta, hundred thousand, and ten thousand worlds, he passed over as many worlds as there are steps.
Bhiká¹£us!

That person takes a step beyond worlds as numerous as the dust particles in those worlds, and in this way, that person walks for hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas of asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of kalpas, placing a dust particle with each step, and in this way, all the dust particles are used up.
Bhiká¹£us!
In this way, worlds as numerous as those dust particles, whether filled with dust particles or not, are filled with dust particles again, and more are placed in worlds in the ten directions.
Bhiká¹£us!
Beyond those worlds, whether filled with dust particles or not, all those worlds, from the water level below to the peak of existence above, are filled with dust particles.
Bhiká¹£us!
What do you think? Can the number of those dust particles be known?
The bhiká¹£us said:
No, World-Honored One!
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

The number of those dust motes can be known, but the number of those Buddhas with the same name ÅšÄkyamuni, whose mothers with the same name MahÄmÄyÄ gave birth to them, whose fathers with the same name Åšuddhodana were their kings, whose cities with the same name Kapila were their birthplaces, whose chief disciples with the same names ÅšÄriputra and MaudgalyÄyana were their attendants, and whose personal disciples with the same name Ä€nanda were their disciples, cannot be known.
Moreover, bhiká¹£us!

There is a third person who takes as many dust motes from those worlds as there are dust motes in those worlds, and in one step passes through as many worlds as there are dust motes, and in that many hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of nayutas of asaá¹ƒkhyeyas of eons, he walks and places down a dust mote, and in this way he exhausts all the dust motes.

There is a fourth person who takes as many dust motes as there are dust motes in those worlds, and whether he places them down or not, from the bottom to the water level, up to the peak of existence, fills it with dust motes.
Bhiká¹£us!

However, the mothers of those Buddhas with the same name ÅšÄkyamuni, the fathers with the same name, the worlds with the same name, the disciples with the same name, the attendants with the same name, and the Buddhas with the same name cannot be known in number.

In this way, the fifth person, the sixth, the seventh, the eighth, the ninth, and the tenth person.
Furthermore, bhiká¹£us!

There is also an eleventh person. This person, in those fine dust motes, takes one fine dust mote and breaks it into as many parts as there are fine dust motes in the worlds in the ten directions. Just as one fine dust mote is broken into as many parts, so too are the remaining fine dust motes all broken into as many parts as there are fine dust motes in the worlds.

Suppose there are people who, in the buddha-lands beyond those buddha-lands as many as the dust particles in a world system, travel in one step, and in this way, with the speed of the divine power of swiftness, travel through the worlds in the eastern direction for immeasurable and limitless eons, and in each world system they place down one dust particle from the east, continuing in this way until all the dust particles are used up, whether they are placed down or not, from the bottom to the water level, up to the peak of existence, filled with dust particles;
in the same way, in the southern direction, up to the ten directions, from the bottom to the water level, up to the peak of existence, filled with dust particles.
